source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: The a-c impedance measurements were made for oxide films formed in high temperature steam on Zry-2 with varying precipitate distributions.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: TEM and EDX analyses were also carried out on precipitates in oxide films.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: The electrical resistivity of oxide films tends to increase with an increase in nodular corrosion resistance.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: with the $\beta$ -quenched samples having the highest resistivity.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: The resistivity tended to increase with a decrease in average precipitate size.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: EDX analyses showed that precipitates in oxide films dissolved into oxide matrix during the corrosion process in high temperature steam.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Very fine precipitates in $\beta$ -quenched Zry-2 would have disappeared early in the corrosion process.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Zry-2 is a zirconiumbased alloy consisting of $1 . 5 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ tin, $0 . 1 5 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ iron, $0 . 1 0 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ chromium, and $0 . 0 5 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ nickel.
composition_raw: 1.5 wt% tin, 0.15 wt% iron, 0.10 wt% chromium, 0.05 wt% nickel

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: The tin is in solid solution, but most of the iron. chromium, and nickel precipitated from Zry-2 matrix to form intermetallic compounds whose size and distribution are two of the most important metallurgical variables affecting nodular corrosion.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: It has been confirmed by out-of-pile high temperature corrosion tests that Zry-2 with a smaller average size and higher density of precipitates is more resistant to nodular corrosion than that having fewer but larger precipitates $\left[ I - \mathcal { G } \right]$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Test materials were Zry-2 tubes of four different lots and different qualities with respect to corrosion susceptibility.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubes were fabricated through conventional fabrication processes (Fig. 1) to the final size of $1 2 . 5 2 \mathrm { m m }$ outer diameter and $0 . 8 6 \mathrm { m m }$ thickness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubes were fabricated through conventional fabrication processes (Fig. 1) to the final size of $1 2 . 5 2 \mathrm { m m }$ outer diameter and $0 . 8 6 \mathrm { m m }$ thickness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Test samples $1 5 \mathrm { m m }$ wide and $3 0 \mathrm { m m }$ long were cut from the tubes after flattening tubes along a circumferential direction.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Test samples $1 5 \mathrm { m m }$ wide and $3 0 \mathrm { m m }$ long were cut from the tubes after flattening tubes along a circumferential direction.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Some samples were solution-treated at $1 0 5 0 \mathrm { { ^circ C } }$ for 3 min and then water-quenched.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: The quenching was done in a sealed quartz ampule that was evacuated to lower than about $1 0 ^ { - 3 }$ Pa.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: All samples were annealed at $5 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ for $^ { 3 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ to relieve residual stresses formed by the flattening or the quenching.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: Samples were oxidized in $1 0 . 5 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ steam at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 1 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ to form oxide films for the a-c impedance measurements.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: Almost uniform and black/shiny oxide films were formed by the oxidation.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: Test samples showed only slight differences in uniform corrosion resistance under this condition.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: Oxide thickness was about 0.6 to $0 . 8 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: Samples were immersed in an aqueous solution containing $0 . 1 \mathrm { \ m o l / L }$ NaOH and placed between a platinum counter electrode and an $\mathbf { A } \mathbf { g } / \mathbf { A } \mathbf { g } \mathbf { C l }$ reference electrode.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: After the immersion, samples were held for more than $^ { 1 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ to stabilize the open circuit potential

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: The a-c voltage waves were applied between a sample and a counter electrode with an amplitude of $2 0 \mathrm { m V }$ around the open circuit potential

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: Frequencies of the voltage waves ranged from $5 ~ \times ~ 1 0 ^ { - 4 }$ to $1 0 ^ { 5 } ~ \mathrm { H z }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk2
evidence_span: Accuracies of current and potential measurement were $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { n A }$ and $0 . 1 ~ \mathrm { \mathfrak { m V } }$ , respectively.

evidence_span: A large number of micropores were preferentially located along grain boundaries. The diameter of the grain boundary pores was about 1 to 2 nm, which was slightly larger than that of pores dispersed within oxide grains.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Almost equiaxed grains were formed in the oxide; their size was about 20 to 30 nm diameter.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk3

evidence_span: The electrical resistivity of oxide films tends to increase with an increase in the nodular corrosion resistance.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: EDX analyses showed that there was a dissolution of precipitates in oxide films during the corrosion process.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: The dissolution rate was highest for iron, then nickel, and lowest for chromium.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: In the case of the $\beta$ -quenched samples, the very fine precipitates, which had been densely decorated along lamellae boundaries of Zry-2 matrix, had only slight short-circuit effects on electronic conduction through oxide films.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: It is presumed that the improvement in nodular corrosion resistance by $\beta$ -quenching is attributable not to short-circuit effects but to a change in oxide properties induced by an increase in the amount of iron, nickel, and chromium retained in the matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: The d-c resistivity tends to decrease with a decrease in the nodular corrosion resistance of the samples.

evidence_span: All measurements in the present experiment were performed at room temperature.
